text: This is a download from BBC Learning English. To find out more, visit our website.
Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.
speaker: Neil

text: And I'm Sam.
People collect all kinds of things for a hobby, from stamps and coins to comics and football stickers.
speaker: Neil

text: Do you collect anything, Sam?
I used to have a big collection of Pokemon cards, but I have no idea where they are now.
Well, maybe you should start looking for them because all kinds of collectibles,
that's objects that people want to collect, are selling for big money on the internet.
speaker: collectablesnon-fungible

text: It's all part of a new tech craze called non-fundable tokens or NFTs for short.
Non-fundable tokens?
Basically, NFTs are unique one of a kind items that can be bought and sold like any physical object,
but only exist in the digital world.
speaker: Neil

text: Tokens can be thought of as certificates of ownership for these virtual possessions.
Hmm, okay. I understand the token part, but what does non-fundable mean?
If something is ‘fungible’ it can be interchanged, like money for example.
speaker: fungible

text: With money, you can swap a £10 note for two £5 notes and it will have the same value.
Ah, so something non-fundable cannot be interchanged with something else.
Is that because it has special features that make it unique?
Exactly. Imagine something totally unique like the Mona Lisa.
speaker: Neil

text: You can take a photo of the painting or buy a copy of it,
but there will only ever be the one original painting.
Ah, I can see that the Mona Lisa is one of a kind and extremely valuable,
but it's not for sale on the internet.
True, but lots of other things are, from signed celebrity artwork to virtual football cards
speaker: Neil

text: NFTs are like autographed photos.
Collectors want something no one else has,
even though there's nothing physical they actually own and keep.
And the value of NFTs is going up and up?
Massively. A digital sticker of French footballer,
speaker: Neil

text: Kilian and Bappe recently sold for £25,000,
which reminds me of my quiz question, Sam.
In June 2021, Satin Berners-Lee sold the original source code he used to invent the Worldwide Web,
as an NFT at a charity auction.
The sale started at $1,000, but how much did the source code eventually sell for?
Was it a $5,4,000?
B $5,4 million? Or C $5,4 billion?
If you're asking me how much the internet sold for,
speaker: Neil

text: I'd say C $5,4 billion.
Okay, Sam will find out later if that's right.
Satin Berners-Lee famously never made any money from the Worldwide Web,
insisting that his invention should be free for everyone.
speaker: Neil

text: But the world of NFTs is controversial,
and not everyone thinks Satin should be getting involved.
That's certainly the view of Shona Gosh,
technology editor at the insider website,
as she told BBC World Service Programme TechTent.
I think there's a balance to be struck between exploring new technologies,
speaker: Neil

text: and Satin Berners-Lee is an amazing figure.
But NFTs are a Wild West,
not everything associated with NFTs are rogue,
but these so-called digital collectibles are going for lots of money.
Internet NFTs are very new and there are no rules controlling what can be sold
speaker: wild west

text: and for how much.
So Shona describes them as a Wild West.
The Wild West means a situation where people can do whatever they want,
because there are no laws or controls,
like the early history of the western part of the United States.
She also calls some things about NFTs
speaker: rogue

text: rogue, behaving differently from what's normal or expected,
often in a way that causes damage.
Love them or hate them, there are strong opinions on both sides of the NFT debate,
as Rory Ketlin Jones, presenter of the BBC World Services TechTent, explains.
To some NFTs are a brilliant innovation
speaker: digital artefactspyramid scheme

text: which is promised to put a value on those digital artifacts,
to others they're little more than a dubious pyramid scheme,
with a damaging impact on the environment,
because of the way the tokens are created.
Some people are suspicious of the large amounts of money collectors are willing to pay,
comparing NFTs to pyramid schemes.
Business tricks or scams, where money is obtained dishonestly.
But for others, NFTs are a legitimate and useful way to put a price on rare digital artifacts.
Items such as images, videos, and music that are produced and stored as electronic versions.
speaker: digital artefacts

text: Items like, for example, the original source code for the internet.
So how much money did Satim Bernas-Lee raise for charity when he sold it off, Neil?
In my quiz question, I asked Sam how much the NFT for the original internet source code
sold for at auction.
speaker: Neil

text: And I said, see, $5.4 billion.
You were… wrong! In fact it was less - 5.4 million
speaker: Neil

text: but still far too expensive for me to collect.
Now I'm wondering how much my Pokemon card collection would sell for,
if only I could find it.
Well, while you look for your collection, Sam, let's recap the vocabulary from this program,
speaker: digital artefacts

text: all about NFTs, which are digital artifacts,
or items that are produced and stored as electronic versions.
NFTs are virtual collectibles, desirable objects that people search for and collect.
And they are non-fundable, meaning they have special and unique characteristics
that cannot be interchanged with anything else
speaker: non-fungible

text: If something is a rogue, it behaves in a different way from what's normal or expected,
often causing damage.
The wild west describes a chaotic situation without laws or controls.
speaker: The wild west

text: And finally, a pyramid scheme is a business scam where money is gained dishonestly.
If you'd like to know more about non-fundable tokens, Bitcoin and other trending internet
topics, there's plenty to find on the BBC website.
speaker: non-fungible

text: And for more interesting conversation and useful vocabulary,
remember to join us again soon.
Here at 6 Minute English. Bye for now.
Bye.
